name: Sweetened Condensed Coconut Milk Rolls
description: Use regular sweetened condensed milk and unsalted butter if a dairy-free result isn't important to you. See the main post for a video primer for shaping the rolls. Check out this sweetened condensed coconut milk recipe, if you want to go extra DIY.
recipeIngredient: 1  packet ((2 1/4 teaspoons) fast-acting “instant” yeast, such as SAF Red Star brand)
1 1/2 tablespoon coconut oil (virgin or refined), (melted and at room temperature)
3 1/4 cups (16.25 oz) bread flour, plus more for dusting
1 tablespoon sweetened condensed coconut milk diluted with 2 to 3 teaspoons water ((aim for a brushable consistency))

recipeInstructions.text: To make the dough in a stand mixer, in the mixer bowl, dissolve the sugar in 1/3 cup of the water. Sprinkle on the yeast, stir to combine and let sit to soften, about 3 minutes.
recipeInstructions.name: To make the dough in a stand mixer, in the mixer bowl, dissolve the sugar in 1/3 cup of the water. Sprinkle on the yeast, stir to combine and let sit to soften, about 3 minutes.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the remaining 2/3 cup water and the sweetened condensed coconut milk, coconut oil, and salt.  With the paddle attachment in place, run the machine on “stir” or low for about 15 seconds to combine. Pause the machine, and add the flour. Run the machine on low for about 1 minute, or until a shaggy dough forms. Turn off the machine and let sit, uncovered, for 5 minutes to further hydrate.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the remaining 2/3 cup water and the sweetened condensed coconut milk, coconut oil, and salt.  With the paddle attachment in place, run the machine on “stir” or low for about 15 seconds to combine. Pause the machine, and add the flour. Run the machine on low for about 1 minute, or until a shaggy dough forms. Turn off the machine and let sit, uncovered, for 5 minutes to further hydrate.

recipeInstructions.text: Meanwhile, grease a medium or large bowl with coconut or regular oil (whichever is handiest) and set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Meanwhile, grease a medium or large bowl with coconut or regular oil (whichever is handiest) and set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Remove the paddle attachment and attach the dough hook. Run the mixer on medium for several minutes to combine the dough into a smooth, elastic dough. On  my machine, the dough eventually sticks and climbs up the dough hook. Transfer the dough onto a lightly floured work surface and knead it to form a smooth roundish shape, about 1 minute. Press on it with a finger and the slightly sticky, somewhat soft dough (think a Post-it) will gently spring back.
recipeInstructions.name: Remove the paddle attachment and attach the dough hook. Run the mixer on medium for several minutes to combine the dough into a smooth, elastic dough. On  my machine, the dough eventually sticks and climbs up the dough hook. Transfer the dough onto a lightly floured work surface and knead it to form a smooth roundish shape, about 1 minute. Press on it with a finger and the slightly sticky, somewhat soft dough (think a Post-it) will gently spring back.

recipeInstructions.text: To make the dough by hand, use a large bowl, combine the ingredients as instructed but stir the flour in with a sturdy spatula. Rest the shaggy result then knead the dough initially in the bowl, and when it comes together, transfer the dough to a lightly floured work surface. Hand knead it for 8 to 10 minutes until smooth and elastic. You may have to add a bit of water (moisten your hands to add that clinging moisture).
recipeInstructions.name: To make the dough by hand, use a large bowl, combine the ingredients as instructed but stir the flour in with a sturdy spatula. Rest the shaggy result then knead the dough initially in the bowl, and when it comes together, transfer the dough to a lightly floured work surface. Hand knead it for 8 to 10 minutes until smooth and elastic. You may have to add a bit of water (moisten your hands to add that clinging moisture).

recipeInstructions.text: Put the dough into the greased bowl, cover with plastic wrap, then set in a warm, draft-free place to rise until doubled, about 1 hour.  Punch down the dough, then pull up each of the four corners and fold it to the center. When done, flip the dough over so the folds face the bowl bottom. Recover and let rise again in a warm place, about 45 minutes. Or refrigerate overnight, bringing it back to room temperature before shaping and baking.
recipeInstructions.name: Put the dough into the greased bowl, cover with plastic wrap, then set in a warm, draft-free place to rise until doubled, about 1 hour.  Punch down the dough, then pull up each of the four corners and fold it to the center. When done, flip the dough over so the folds face the bowl bottom. Recover and let rise again in a warm place, about 45 minutes. Or refrigerate overnight, bringing it back to room temperature before shaping and baking.

recipeInstructions.text: Grease a 9-inch square baking pan (or similar size pan). If you want, like the bottom with parchment and let the paper extend about 1 inch beyond the pan rim for easier removal later.
recipeInstructions.name: Grease a 9-inch square baking pan (or similar size pan). If you want, like the bottom with parchment and let the paper extend about 1 inch beyond the pan rim for easier removal later.

recipeInstructions.text: Turn the dough onto your work surface. Cut it in half. Working with one of halves, shape it into a rope about 1 ½ to 2 inches wide. Cut the dough rope crosswise into 6 pieces. (If you want smaller rolls, make the rope smaller and longer to cut 8, 10 or 12 pieces.) Roughly roll each dough piece into a ball, then pull, tuck, and gather the edges of dough toward the center to form a small mound. Aim to create a taught small ball (see the video in the main post for guidance, if needed). Put the dough balls, seam side down, in a 9-inch square pan, arranging them as rows. Repeat with the other half of the dough.
recipeInstructions.name: Turn the dough onto your work surface. Cut it in half. Working with one of halves, shape it into a rope about 1 ½ to 2 inches wide. Cut the dough rope crosswise into 6 pieces. (If you want smaller rolls, make the rope smaller and longer to cut 8, 10 or 12 pieces.) Roughly roll each dough piece into a ball, then pull, tuck, and gather the edges of dough toward the center to form a small mound. Aim to create a taught small ball (see the video in the main post for guidance, if needed). Put the dough balls, seam side down, in a 9-inch square pan, arranging them as rows. Repeat with the other half of the dough.

recipeInstructions.text: Cover with plastic wrap (lightly oil it if you fear the dough touching the plastic), then let rise in a warm spot until doubled, about 1 hour. Roughly 15 minutes before the rolls have risen enough, preheat the oven to 350°F, with a rack in the middle position. Brush with half of the diluted condense coconut milk. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes, until golden brown on top.
recipeInstructions.name: Cover with plastic wrap (lightly oil it if you fear the dough touching the plastic), then let rise in a warm spot until doubled, about 1 hour. Roughly 15 minutes before the rolls have risen enough, preheat the oven to 350°F, with a rack in the middle position. Brush with half of the diluted condense coconut milk. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes, until golden brown on top.

recipeInstructions.text: Cool on a rack for 5 minutes before brushing the remaining diluted sweetened condensed milk on the top for a lightly sweet finish. Let cool for 20 to 30 minutes before removing the rolls by inverting the pan and quickly flipping the rolls back onto their bottoms (or, lift the parchment out of the pan). Finish cooling on the rack. Enjoy warm or at room temperature.
recipeInstructions.name: Cool on a rack for 5 minutes before brushing the remaining diluted sweetened condensed milk on the top for a lightly sweet finish. Let cool for 20 to 30 minutes before removing the rolls by inverting the pan and quickly flipping the rolls back onto their bottoms (or, lift the parchment out of the pan). Finish cooling on the rack. Enjoy warm or at room temperature.

review.reviewBody: I made these for my in-laws and they loved them. They asked if I can make them ube-flavored. I have dried ube powder, but don’t know how to add it to the dough without ruining the bread. What do you suggest?

I made these today for the 1st time as my son has severe allergies to eggs & dairy so findings good recipes is tricky! These turned out FANTASTIC, so good!!!! Will definitely be keeping this one as a “go to”for Holidays. Only modification I made was I used All Purpose flours as that’s what I had on hand & used roughly 5 cups of flour total to make my dough form. Thank you so very much!

I can't wait to make these for Thanksgiving in place of my usual potato rolls and I only hope I don't eat half of them before we begin feasting with our bubble of four. Since I know there will be lots of leftovers I am also looking forward to enjoying them for little turkey and cranberry sandwich buns.
A word on the video issue: I believe the problem is that a virus- or ad-blocking utility could be blocking the video along with the advertising. When I disabled my blocker your helpful video popped into view.
Happy baking!
